document: This document summarizes the main points covered in Lecture 8 on Dynamic Programming.

questions.question: Dynamic programming is an algorithm design technique for optimization problems such as minimizing or maximizing a value.
Sub‑problems in dynamic programming are always independent of each other.
Memoization can be used with a top‑down (recursion + caching) approach to dynamic programming.
A bottom‑up dynamic programming algorithm requires storing the results of subproblems in a table.
The memoized factorial function has a time complexity of Θ(n).
Computing Fibonacci recursively without dynamic programming has an exponential time complexity O(2ⁿ).
The bottom‑up Fibonacci algorithm runs in linear time and uses O(n) space.
A binomial coefficient C(n,k) can be computed by filling a table using the recurrence C(n,k)=C(n−1,k)+C(n−1,k−1).
The base cases for computing binomial coefficients are C(n,0)=1 and C(n,n)=1.
Dynamic programming solves problems by combining solutions to sub‑problems.
Dynamic programming reduces computation by solving sub‑problems in a bottom‑up fashion.
In dynamic programming, the solution to one subproblem may affect solutions to other subproblems of the same problem.
The recurrence relation for Fibonacci numbers is F(n)=F(n−1)+F(n−2).
Levenshtein distance is a method used to compare two strings.
The brute‑force factorial algorithm has a time complexity of O(n²).
The memoized factorial implementation uses a lookup table to store intermediate results.
The bottom‑up Fibonacci dynamic programming algorithm requires re‑computing subproblems each time it is called.
Computing C(n,k) by dynamic programming has a time efficiency of O(nk).
The space efficiency for the binomial coefficient dynamic programming solution is O(1).
Sub‑problems in dynamic programming may share sub‑sub‑problems.
